metadata.title: Design and preparation of hydrated MgAl supported Cu catalysts with high alkalinity by MOCVD for the hydrogenolysis of cellulose

IMAGE-HIGH-RES APCATA 16274 S0926-860X(17)30261-2 10.1016/j.apcata.2017.06.012 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 1H NMR spectra of CuII(hfac)2. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 IR spectra of the supports and catalysts. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD patterns of the catalysts with different supports before and after reaction. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 TEM images of the (a) 5%Cu/Mg3Al1, (b, c) 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalysts before reaction, and the (d, e) 5%Cu/Mg3Al1-R, (f) 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1-R catalysts after reaction. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 CO2-TPD profiles of the supports and catalysts. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 The influence of amount of Cu loading on the hydrogenolysis of cellulose (Reaction conditions: 2wt% cellulose, 0.4g of the hydration catalysts, 240°C, 6MPa, 5h). Fig. 6 Fig. 7 The influence of reaction time on the hydrogenolysis of cellulose (Reaction conditions: 2wt% cellulose, 0.4g of 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst, 240°C, 6MPa). Fig. 7 Fig. 8 The influence of the starting concentration of cellulose on the hydrogenolysis of cellulose (Reaction conditions: 0.4g of 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst, 240°C, 6MPa, 5h). Fig. 8 Fig. 9 The recyclability test of the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst for the hydrogenolysis of cellulose (Reaction conditions: 2wt% cellulose, 0.4g of catalyst, 240°C, 6MPa, 5h). Fig. 9 Table 1 The textural and basic properties of the supports and catalysts. Table 1 Samples Surface area (m2 g−1) Pore volume (cm3 g−1) Mean pore size (nm) Number of base sites (μmolg−2) Base sites density a (μmolm−2) Mg3Al1 304 0.77 10.0 115 0.378 H-Mg3Al1 233 0.46 8.0 561 2.407 5%Cu/Mg3Al1 184 0.65 17.4 252 1.370 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 104 0.31 12.0 599 5.761 a The base sites density was obtained from the ratio of the number of base sites to the surface area of catalysts. Table 2 N2O titration results of the catalysts with different Cu loading. Table 2 Samples MSA (m2 g−1 Cu) Øav (nm) 5%Cu/Mg3Al1 85 7.1 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 171 3.6 1%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 180 3.4 3%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 178 3.4 10%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 39 14.7 Feature Article Design and preparation of hydrated MgAl supported Cu catalysts with high alkalinity by MOCVD for the hydrogenolysis of cellulose Zihui Xiao Tianjin Key Laboratory of Advanced Functional Porous Materials, Institute for New Energy Materials & Low-Carbon Technologies, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Tianjin University of Technology, Tianjin 300384, China Tianjin Key Laboratory of Advanced Functional Porous Materials Institute for New Energy Materials & Low-Carbon Technologies School of Materials Science and Engineering Tianjin University of Technology Tianjin 300384 China Graphical abstract A stable and high alkaline hydrated MgAl supported Cu catalyst was prepared by MOCVD for the hydrogenolysis of cellulose. The unhydrated and hydrated MgAl supported Cu catalysts were successfully prepared by metal-organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) method. The structure properties of metal-organic precursor, supports and catalysts were determined by 1H NMR, FTIR, XRD, N2 physisorption, TEM, N2O titration, and CO2-TPD. The hydration of support had a significant effect on the structure of the final catalysts. The hydrated Mg3Al1 support was benefited to the adsorption and deposition of CuII(hfac)2, resulting in the decrease of the reduction decomposition temperature. Due to the restoration of the layered structure, the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst had a low BET surface area and pore volume. However, it exhibited higher base sites density and got better performance for cellulose hydrogenolysis compared to the 5%Cu/Mg3Al1 catalyst, which suggested that the hydration before reaction was superior to that during reaction for the catalytic performance, due to the competition between water and products (alcohols with strong adsorption) during reaction, resulting in a decrease in the concentration of in-situ formed surface OH− and the amount of base sites. It was noteworthy that unobvious change in phases of the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst was observed before and after reaction, which provided a promising way to establish the relationship between structure and catalytic performance. Keywords Metal-organic chemical vapor deposition CuII(hfac)2 Hydration Cellulose hydrogenolysis Base sites density 1 Introduction The transformation of biomass to renewable chemicals and fuels is of importance towards both decreasing the dependence on fossil resources and reducing CO2 emissions. Recently, much effort has been taken to develop the novel catalysts and technologies for the conversion of cellulose to low carbon polyols (≤C6) [1–8]. On account of the great stability and insolubility of cellulose, it generally needs to be converted into water-soluble saccharides by hydrolysis with the aid of H+ original from inorganic acid or water at high temperature and pressure, or by degradation under alkaline condition [9], subsequently decomposed and hydrogenated to products with low molecular weight over the bifunctional catalysts (hydrogenation sites, acidic sites or alkaline sites). For the alkaline catalysts system, the application of inorganic base would no doubt increase the cost of equipment and product separation, and lead to the formation of a large amount of waste water. Thus, the design of the bifunctional catalysts with solid alkaline sites has been attracted much attention. In our previous work, the CuMgAl catalyst was proved to exhibit great catalytic performance in the hydrogenolysis of cellulose [8], which was attributed to the promotional effect of the hydrated OH− due to the “memory effect” of hydrotalcite as Brønsted bases. In other words, the structure of catalyst was changed during the reaction, which led to the fact that it was hard to establish the relationship between structure properties and catalytic performance. In the case of conventional co-precipitation method, a variety of post-treatment must be performed, including calcination and reduction at high temperature, thus the structure of hydrotalcite is hard to maintain. In order to surmount it, a new preparation protocol needs to be developed. On the basic of the above, one solution is that the hydrated MgAl could be prepared first, and then copper nanoparticles are loaded onto the hydrated MgAl. While the key problem is that the structure of hydrated MgAl should be maintained in the loading process. The liquid-phase reduction has been widespread applied for the preparation of supported catalysts due to the mild reaction condition, however, the addition of reductant lead to the introduction of impurities, which would not be thoroughly removed without difficulty. Metal-organic chemical vapor deposition offers several advantages superior to liquid-phase reduction. The main advantage is the absence of a solvent. Solvents may block pores and the inner surface of the substrate thus leading to low and inhomogeneous loading. The removal of a solvent usually causes additional preparation steps and thus additional costs. Generally, residues from CVD precursors are easily removed [10]. Thus, organic metal complexes as precursors for preparation of highly dispersed metal or oxide catalysts have attracted considerable interest for investigations. A MOCVD precursor has to possess adequate volatility and a sufficiently large temperature “window” between evaporation and decomposition. In addition, a MOCVD precursor needs to be sufficiently stable at room temperature when stored over a long period of time, and it should not undergo any decomposition at the evaporation temperatures necessary to achieve adequate gas-phase transport [11]. Every organometallic precursor contains organic ligands attached to the central metal atom. Among the bidentate ligands, hexafluoroacetylacetonate (hfac) is one of the most widely used ligand because it can form metal-ligand bonds with transition metals that do not form stable carbonyls. Therefore, CuII(hfac)2 was synthesized as MOCVD precursor. As known, the beginning dehydroxylation of vicinal OH groups in the hydrotalcite occurred at around 260°C [12]. For keeping the structure of hydrated MgAl, the decomposition temperature of the chosen MOCVD precursor should be lower than 260°C. G. Nuesca et al. reported that the CuII(hfac)2 could be reduced to Cu0 in UHV by exposure to atomic hydrogen at 177°C [13]. Based on this, there is reasonable to believe that highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles loaded onto hydrated MgAl catalyst could be obtained by MOCVD. In this work, a series of MgAl supported Cu catalysts was prepared successfully by MOCVD. And the effect of hydration on the structure and catalytic performance of the final catalyst was also investigated. It was noteworthy that the phase structure of hydrated MgAl was kept during the reaction. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation The metal-organic precursor CuII(hfac)2 is synthesized in one step by a modification of the literature procedure [14]. Typically, 0.18g of Cu2O powder was stirred in 15mL of anhydrous tetrahydrofuran (THF). A 0.35mL of hexafluoroacetylacetone in 10mL of THF solution was added dropwisely to the stirred solution. The reaction was protected under a rapid flow of high pure nitrogen. Initially, the reaction mixture was clear with the brick-red cuprous oxide being suspended in solution. As the hexafluoroacetylacetone was added, the solution becomes a dark green color. After final addition, the reaction mixture was stirred for 45min and the excess Cu2O was filtered off. The dark green solution was concentrated under mild vacuum on a rotary evaporator with a bath temperature of 35°C. The remaining dry solid was then sublimed at 45°C and under 0.1Torr before the final green crystal was collected from the sublimation device. Mg3Al1 hydrotalcite (Mg/Al molar ratio) was prepared by coprecipitation from aqueous solutions at 70°C. Solution A containing appropriated amounts of Na2CO3 and NaOH (OH−/CO3 2− =5 and CO3 2− +OH− =0.6M, 100mL) was slowly dropped under vigorous stirring to solution B containing nitrate precursors (Mg+Al=0.15M, 200mL). The formed precipitates were aged in their mother liquor for 4h at 70°C and then filtered, washed with boiling distilled water until Na+ was no longer detected in the filtrate, and dried at 100°C overnight. The formed hydrotalcites precursors were decomposed in air at 500°C for 2h in order to obtain the corresponding Mg3Al1 oxide. The hydration of Mg3Al1 oxide (0.9g) was performed in 19.5mL of ethanol and 45.5mL of water mixture solution for 4h at 40°C under stirring with the protection of N2. After the hydration process, the sample was filtered, washed with ethanol, and vacuum dried at 60°C overnight yield to H-Mg3Al1. The Cu deposition onto the Mg3Al1 oxide or H-Mg3Al1 was achieved by MOCVD of CuII(hfac)2. Prior to Cu deposition, the CuII(hfac)2 was adsorbed onto supports under vacuum at 60°C for 12h after mechanical mixing. And then the deposition was carried out in the mixture of 50% H2 in Ar (50mLmin−1) at 200°C for 2h. The obtained catalysts designed as x%Cu/Mg3Al1 or x%Cu/H-Mg3Al1, where x was the theoretical loading amount of Cu. After reaction, the recycled catalysts designed as 5%Cu/Mg3Al1-R or 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1-R. 2.2 Characterization Infrared transmission spectra were recorded in the range of 400–4000cm−1 by a FTIR spectrometer (Nicolet iN10 MX & iS10, ThermoFisher). The KBr pellet technique was applied for determining the IR spectra of the samples. 1H NMR spectra was recorded at room temperature on a Bruker AVANCE III HD 500MHz spectrometer. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) data were measured on a Shimadzu XRD-7000S diffractometer with a Cu Kα monochromatized radiation source (λ=1.5418Å), operated at 40KV and 30mA. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were measured by static N2 physisorption at 77K with a Quantachrome Instruments Autosorb-iQ-C automated gas sorption analyzer. Before the N2 physisorption measurement, all samples of approximately 0.1-0.2g were heated to 150°C under vacuum (10−3 Torr) for at least 3h to remove adsorbed impurities. The specific surface area was calculated by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. The total pore volume was derived from the adsorbed N2 volume at a relative pressure of approximately 0.99, and the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method was used to calculate the pore size distributions according to the desorption branch of the isotherms. Temperature-programmed desorption of carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD) analyses of the catalysts were performed on a Micromeritic sautochem II 2910 automated catalyst characterization system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) to measure the CO2 desorption and an on-line mass spectrometer (Omini-star, GSD-300) to detect any organic or inorganic species in the effluent stream during the CO2-TPD experiment. Usually, 0.1g of a sample was loaded in a quartz reactor and pretreated in He at 300°C for 1h. After the sample was cooled to 50°C in He stream, the sample was exposed to pure CO2 (20mLmin−1) for 1h until completely adsorbed saturation. The physisorbed CO2 was removed by passing He over the catalyst at 50°C for 1h. The CO2-TPD of the pre-adsorbed catalyst was performed under He flow at a temperature ramp of 10°C from 50 to 500°C, while monitoring the thermal conductive detector (TCD) signals. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) was performed by using a FEI Tecnai G2 F30 TEM, operated at 200kV. Copper metal surface area was calculated from a two-step analysis consisting of (i) N2O oxidation of Cu to Cu2O and (ii) H2 temperature-programmed-reduction of the formed Cu2O surface species (s-TPR). For the analysis, a Micromeritics autochem II 2910 automated catalyst characterization system equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) was used. The measurement process was similar to the reported in reference [15] apart from the temperature and time of in situ pre-reduction (200°C, 60min). Cu metal surface area, MSA, and average copper particle size, Øav were calculated. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation Cellulose conversion was performed in a 50mL stainless steel autoclave with mechanical stirrer and an electric temperature controller, operated under H2 pressure of 6.0MPa at 240°C. The cellulose (Avicel pH-101, CAS: 9004-34-6) was directly used without any treatment. The liquid products were analyzed with a shimadzu LC-20A equipped with a Refractive Index Detector (CAPCELL PAK NH2 UG80S5 column: 4.6 mm×250mm), and a 7890F gas chromatograph equipped with a flame ionization detector (FFAP GC column: 30m×0.32 mm×0.5μm). While the gas products were analysed with a 7890F gas chromatograph equipped with thermal conductivity detector (TDX-01 column: 4 mm×2m).The conversion of the cellulose was determined by the change of cellulose weight before and after the reaction. The yield of liquid product was calculated from the equation: yield (%)=(weight of target product)/(weight of cellulose put into the reactor)×100%. 3 Results and discussion 1H NMR spectra of CuII(hfac)2 was record as shown in Fig. 1 . Apart from the solvent peak, a single peak centered at 3.68ppm was observed in the 1H NMR of CuII(hfac)2 in CDCl3 that corresponded to the protons of −CH2 group from the hexafluoroacetylacetone. The NMR data unambiguously confirmed that the CuII(hfac)2 precursor with high purity was successfully synthesized. In order to examining the influence of hydration on the catalysts structure, the IR spectra of the catalysts prepared under different conditions are presented in Fig. 2 . According to previous work [16,17], the corresponding IR band assignments and associated frequencies for both fingerprint IR spectra are also shown in Fig. 2. The spectrum of H-Mg3Al1 exhibited a typical broad band at 3471cm−1, which was attributed to the stretching mode of hydrogen-bonded hydroxyl groups from the brucite-like layers and interlayer water. The shoulder at 3050cm−1 was assigned to hydrogen bonding between water and carbonate in the interlayer, whereas the band at 1641cm−1 was the H2O bending vibration. The vibration of the carbonates (asymmetric stretching) appeared at 1369cm−1 and could be assigned to interlayer carbonates (chelating or bridging bidentate). Mode ν 4 of carbonate anion could be responsible for band at 672 cm−1 [18]. The band at 770cm−1 could be assigned to the translation modes of the hydroxyl groups influenced by the Al3+. After calcination of hydrotalcite (Mg3Al1), the intensity of the bands corresponding to hydroxyl groups and carbonate decreased by dehydroxylation and decomposition of carbonates. It could be concluded that the applied calcination temperature was not sufficient to completely eliminate hydroxyls and carbonates. The absorption band at 1650cm−1 can be assigned to the stretching vibration of CO band of CuII(hfac)2 [16]. Significantly, part of absorption bands below 1000cm−1 disappeared due to the slight decomposition of CuII(hfac)2 after adsorption, regardless of it adsorbed onto the Mg3Al1 or H-Mg3Al1 support. For the 5%Cu/Mg3Al1 catalyst, unobvious change in absorption bands was observed after adsorption and reduction. While the spectra of the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst after reduction was similar to that of the H-Mg3Al1 support, suggesting that adsorbed CuII(hfac)2 on the H-Mg3Al1 could be reduced easily to Cu0 under given conditions. This phenomenon indicated that the surface groups of support significantly affected the deposition temperature of the metal-organic precursor, which was consistent with that reported in reference [13]. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts with different supports before and after reaction. Only a mixed oxide phase MgAlOx (JCPDS 87-0653) was observed in the pattern of the 5%Cu/Mg3Al1 catalyst. While the Cu phase was not detected, which was likely due to the uncompleted decomposition of CuII(hfac)2 resulting in the low loading amount. This was consistent with the observation in IR spectra. For the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst, the original layer structure of support was recovered by hydration, which was assigned to meixnerite (JCPDS 35-0965). Unlike the patterns of the 5%Cu/Mg3Al1 catalyst, a diffraction peak with weak intensity corresponding to Cu could be also distinguished. After reaction (5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1-R and 5%Cu/Mg3Al1-R), the intensity of diffraction peaks was increased, which indicated that the crystallinity for both meixnerite and Cu phases was significantly enhanced. It was noteworthy that unobvious change in phases of the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst was observed before and after reaction, which provided a promising way to establish the relationship between structure and catalytic performance. The structure properties of supports and catalysts were determined by N2 physisorption. As shown in Table 1 , the hydrated support had a low BET surface area and pore volume. The similar result was also observed in reference [19], where a dramatic decrease in the BET surface area (from 253 to 57m2·g−1) after hydration had been reported. It was because of that the micropores vanished during rehydration, and the layer structure was restored resulting in a significant decrease of the BET surface area and total pore volume. Moreover, a decline in surface area for the hydrated support was also probably caused by steric hindrance produced by the OH− and water molecules in the interlayer space. After loading of Cu, a part of pores might be blocked led to a further decrease in the BET surface area and total pore volume. TEM images were recorded to investigate the structure of the catalysts with different supports before and after reaction (Fig. 4 ). For the 5%Cu/Mg3Al1 catalyst, the Cu nanoparticles were not identified, which was likely due to the low loading amount. This was consistent with the observation in XRD and FTIR results. Nevertheless, relatively great dispersed Cu particles could be observed for the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst (Fig. 4c), which was further proved by the detected lattice spacing in HRTEM image (Fig. 4b). The lattice spacing of 0.2091nm and 0.1958nm corresponding to Cu (111) and Meixnerite (018) was determined. During reaction, the adsorbed CuII(hfac)2 could be reduced to Cu at high pressure and temperature, thus more detectable Cu nanoparticles for the 5%Cu/Mg3Al1-R catalyst were observed as shown in Fig. 4d, the corresponding lattice spacing of that was also examined (Fig. 4e). For the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst, no obvious change in particle size was obtained before and after reaction. The average size of Cu particle was about 4nm in both catalysts by statistics and calculation of over 20 particles. CO2-TPD is typically applied to determine the density and strength of base sites in mixed oxides derived from the calcination of hydrotalcites. To establish a correlation between the catalytic activity and the textural and basic properties, CO2-TPD experiments were carried out over the hydrated catalysts as shown in Fig. 5 . Generally, the alkaline species could be assigned according to the temperature at CO2 desorption peaks, corresponding to base sites exhibiting weak (surface hydroxyl groups), moderate (Mm+-O2− pairs) and high strength (O2−), respectively. Visually, various base sites of catalysts were determined and marked in Fig. 5. The number of base sites was estimated by deconvolution and integration of these peaks. Meanwhile, the base sites density (base sites amount per unit surface area of catalysts) was also calculated as listed in Table 1. As expected, three types of base sites presented in the Mg3Al1 support and 5%Cu/Mg3Al1 catalyst were detected. The number of base sites and base sites density were significantly increased after Cu loading, which was because of the Jahn-Teller distortion induced by copper ion, resulting in an increase in number of cationic vacancies [20]. In the case of the H-Mg3Al1 support, the base sites corresponding to the Mm+-O2− pairs were not observed due to the formation of large amount of OH− during hydration. As known, CO2 uptake was caused by different types of carbonate coordination in the interlayer space. Monodentate and bidentate carbonate formation involved low-coordination oxygen anions [21]. While the formation of bicarbonate anions required surface hydroxyl groups. We suggested that the CO2 desorption peak, which centered at about 405°C, could be attributed to the contribution of mainly bidentate carbonates, together with bicarbonate species on the catalyst surface. This was consistent with the report in previous work [17]. During the deposition of Cu, the reduction was performed, resulting in the remove of surface OH− and the exposure of Mm+-O2− pairs as shown in the CO2-TPD profile of the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst. The number of base sites and base sites density for that were increased compared to the H-Mg3Al1 support, which was similar with the observation in the without hydration samples. However, it was noteworthy that these changes were not obvious in the hydration samples, suggesting that the Jahn-Teller effect was weaken after hydration of support. As known, the reactivity of Cu based catalyst was strongly depended on the area of surface Cu, so copper metal surface area was determined by N2O adsorptive decomposition at controlled temperature followed by H2 temperature-programmed-reduction of the Cu2O. The corresponding results are presented in Table 2 . Compared to the 5%Cu/Mg3Al1 catalyst, the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst exhibited larger copper metal surface area (MSA) and smaller copper particle size (Øav). This was due to that large amount of surface group presented in the hydrated support, which was beneficial to the deposition of Cu as observation in FTIR and TEM. Besides, unobvious change in MSA and Øav was observed for the hydrated supported catalysts with low Cu loading (below 5%), while further increasing Cu loading, a significant decrease in MSA was detected, with an increase in Øav, suggesting that high Cu loading led to the aggregation of Cu nanoparticles. The catalytic conversion of cellulose to low carbon polyols was performed at 240°C and 6MPa. Under the given conditions, the cellulose could be converted completely, and the yield of 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PD), ethylene glycol (EG) and glycerol (GLY) was recorded in this work. However, water-soluble oligomers, glucose, sorbitol, mannitol, erythritol, butanediol, propanol, CO, CH4 and some unknown etc. with low content were also detected (not shown). Compared to the 5%Cu/Mg3Al1 catalyst, the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst exhibited better catalytic performance, the corresponding yield of 1,2-PD and EG increased from 14.2% and 23.1% to 22.8% and 24.3%, respectively. This suggested that the hydration before reaction was superior to that during reaction for the catalytic performance, due to the competition between water and products (alcohols with strong adsorption) during reaction, resulting in a decrease in the concentration of in-situ formed surface OH− and the amount of base sites. Certainly, higher copper metal surface area (MSA) and smaller copper particle size was obtained for the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst, which was also responsible for the higher reactivity. As shown in Fig. 6 , the yield of 1,2-PD and EG increased with increasing the amount of Cu loading, which was due to that more active sites presented in the catalyst with higher Cu loading. While further elevating the amount of Cu loading, resulting in the decline of Cu dispersion and increase of particle size as shown in Table 2, thus an opposite tendency for the 1,2-PD and EG yield was observed. The effect of reaction time on hydrogenolysis of cellulose was also investigated, and the results are presented in Fig. 7 . As expected, the yield of 1,2-PD and EG increased to the maximum within 5h and gradually decreased with longer reaction time because of further conversion of it, which was in agreement with the previous observation in reference [22]. In previous work, the CuMgAl catalysts exhibited great performance for the hydrogenolysis of cellulose under high starting concentration [8]. For comparison, the influence of the starting concentration of cellulose for the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst was also examined (Fig. 8 ). It was noted that the yield of 1,2-PD and EG decreased gradually with the increase of cellulose concentration. Similarly, there was almost no coke-like precipitates generated at the cellulose concentration of 10wt% as reported the hydrogenolysis over the CuMgAl catalysts [8]. However, lower yield towards 1,2-PD and EG was obtained over the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst, which might be attributed to the low amount of Cu loading and Cu active sites. The recycling procedure of the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst was performed to examine the stability of the catalysts. In the recycling experiment, the catalyst was separated by centrifugation and washed with ethanol. Then the catalyst was dried at 80°C under vacuum for 12h. Finally, the catalyst was reduced at 200°C for 1h before recycling test. As presented in Fig. 9 , after four recycling, the yield of 1,2-PD and EG was significantly decreased. ICP results (Cu: 0.56mgL−1, Mg: 135.2mgL−1, Al: 0.48mgmL−1) indicated that the decrease of these yields was mainly related to the leaching of Mg, resulting in the decline of catalyst alkalinity. Combined with XRD and TEM results, the crystalline phases were not changed during reaction, and the particle size of Cu was also not changed obviously. Thus, it was reasonable for above speculation. While this needs to further confirm. 4 Conclusions The Mg3Al1 oxide and hydrated Mg3Al1 supported Cu catalysts were prepared by MOCVD. Compared to the unhydrated Mg3Al1 oxide, the hydrated Mg3Al1 was beneficial to the adsorption and deposition of the metal-organic precursor CuII(hfac)2, resulting in the decrease of the reduction decomposition temperature. The hydrated Mg3Al1 support had a low BET surface area and pore volume. This was because of that the micropores vanished during rehydration and the layered structure was restored. After loading of Cu, a part of pores might be blocked led to a further decrease in the BET surface area and total pore volume. Moreover, the hydrated samples exhibited higher base sites density compared to without hydrated samples, and the total base sites density was also significantly increased after Cu loading. The 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst got better performance for the hydrogenolysis of cellulose, which suggested that the hydration before reaction was superior to that during reaction for the catalytic performance, due to the competition between water and products (alcohols with strong adsorption) during reaction, resulting in a decrease in the concentration of in-situ formed surface OH− and the amount of base sites. It was noteworthy that unobvious change in phases of the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst was observed before and after reaction, which provided a promising way to establish the relationship between structure and catalytic performance. In the recycling, the reactivity of the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst was gradually decreased due to the leaching of Mg. coredata.dc:description: The unhydrated and hydrated MgAl supported Cu catalysts were successfully prepared by metal-organic chemical vapor deposition (MOCVD) method. The structure properties of metal-organic precursor, supports and catalysts were determined by 1H NMR, FTIR, XRD, N2 physisorption, TEM, N2O titration, and CO2-TPD. The hydration of support had a significant effect on the structure of the final catalysts. The hydrated Mg3Al1 support was benefited to the adsorption and deposition of CuII(hfac)2, resulting in the decrease of the reduction decomposition temperature. Due to the restoration of the layered structure, the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst had a low BET surface area and pore volume. However, it exhibited higher base sites density and got better performance for cellulose hydrogenolysis compared to the 5%Cu/Mg3Al1 catalyst, which suggested that the hydration before reaction was superior to that during reaction for the catalytic performance, due to the competition between water and products (alcohols with strong adsorption) during reaction, resulting in a decrease in the concentration of in-situ formed surface OH− and the amount of base sites. It was noteworthy that unobvious change in phases of the 5%Cu/H-Mg3Al1 catalyst was observed before and after reaction, which provided a promising way to establish the relationship between structure and catalytic performance.
coredata.dc:title: Design and preparation of hydrated MgAl supported Cu catalysts with high alkalinity by MOCVD for the hydrogenolysis of cellulose
